publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: SIr, you'r the very friend I wish'd to meet with,
I have a large discourse invites your eare
To be an Auditor.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And what concernes it?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The sadly thriving progresse of the loves
Betweene my Lord the Prince, and that great Lady,
Whose insolencie, and never-yet-match'd pride,
Can by no Character be well exprest,
But in her onlie name, the prow'd Erota.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Alas Melitus, I should ghesse, the best
Successe your Prince could find from her, to be
As harsh as the event doth prove: but now
'Tis not a time to pity passionate griefes,
When a whole Kingdome in a manner lies
Upon its death-bed bleeding.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Who can tell
Whether or no, these many plagues at once
Hang over this unhappie Land, for her sake,
That is a monster in it.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Here's the miserie
Of having a child our Prince: else I presume
The bold Venecians had not dar'd to attempt
So bloudie an Invasion.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Yet I wonder
Why, Master Secretarie, still the Senate
So almost superstitiouslie adores,
Gonzalo the Venetian Lord, considering
The outrage of his Countrymen—

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: The Senate
Is wise, and therein just, for this Gonzalo,
Upon a Massacre performed at Sea
By the Admirall of Venice, on a Merchant
Of Candy, when the cause was to be heard
Before the Senate there, in open Court
Professed, that the crueltie the Admirall
Had shewed, deserved not only fine, but death:
For Candy then, and Venice were at peace:
Since when upon a motion in the Senate,
For conquest of our Land, 'tis known for certaine,
That only this Gonzalo dar'd to oppose it,
His reason was, because it too much savoured
Of Lawlesse, and unjust ambition.
The wars were scarce begun, but he (in feare
Of quarrels 'gainst his life) fled from his Countrie,
And hether came, where (to confirme his truth)
I know (Melitus) he, out of his owne store,
Hath monied Cassilanes the Generall.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What, without other pledges then Cassilanes
Bare promise of payment?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: No, it may be
He has some pettie Lordship to retire to:
But this he hath done; now 'tis fit Melitus,
The Senate should be thankefull, otherwise,
They should annihilate one of those Laws,
For which this Kingdome is throughout the world
Unfollowed, and admired.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What Lawes are these? sir,
Let me so much importune you.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: You shall,
And they be worth your knowledge; briefly thus:
Who ere he be that can detect apparantly
Another of ingratitude, for any
Received benefit, the Plaintiffe may
Require the offenders life; unlesse he please
Freely, and willingly to grant remission.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: By which strict Law the Senate is in danger,
Should they neglect Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Right; the Law
Permits a like equalitie to Aliens,
As to a home-borne Patriot.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pray sir the other?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Know Melitus,
The elder Cretans flourished many yeares,
In War, in Peace, unparalel'd, and they
(To spurre heroicke spirits on to vertue)
Enacted that what man so ere he were,
Did noblest in the field against his enemie,
So by the generall voice approv'd, and knowne,
Might at his home-returne, make his demand
For satisfaction, and reward.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: They are
Both famous Lawes indeed. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Master Secretarie,
The Senate is about to sit, and crave
Your presence.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: What, so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: These Letters
Will shew the causes why.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Heaven thou art great,
And worthie to be thanked▪

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Your countenance sir
Doth promise some good tidings.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: O the best
And happiest for this land, that e're was told!
All the Venetian Forces are defeated.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And what doth adde some delight more,
There is amongst the Souldiers a contention
Who shall be the triumpher and it stands
Doubtfull betweene a Father and his Son,
Old Cassilanes, and young Antinous.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why may not both demand it?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: The Law denies it:
But where the Souldiers do not all consent,
The parties in contention, are refer'd
To plead before the Senate; and from them,
Upon an open Audience, to be judg'd
The Chiefe, and then to make demands.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You ravish me
With wonder and delight,

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Come: as we walke,
I shall more fully informe you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Cassilanes, Arcanes, Antinous, and Decius.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Admit no Souldier neare us, till the Senate
Have tooke their places.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You are obey'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Decius, fall off.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Give leave Arcanes:
Young-man come nearer to me: who am I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It were a sin against the piety
Of filiall duty, If I should forget
The debt I owe my father on my knee;
Your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What, so low? canst thou finde joynts,
Yet be an Elephant? Antinous, rise:
Thou wilt belye opinion, and rebate
The ambition of thy gallantry, that they
Whose confidence thou hast bewitched, should see
Their little God of War, kneele to his father,
Though in my hand I did graspe Thunder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir,
For proofe that I acknowledge you the Author
Of giving me my birth, I have discharg'd
A part of my obedience. But if now
You should (as cruell fathers do) proclame
Your right, and Tyrant like usurp the glory
Of my peculiar honours, not deriv'd
From successary, but purchas'd with my bloud,
Then I must stand first Champion for my selfe,
Against all interposers.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Boldly urg'd,
And proudly, I could love thee, did not anger
Consult with just disdaine, in open language
To call thee most ungratefull. Say freely,
Wilt thou resigne the flatteries, whereon
The reeling pillars of a popular breath,
Have rais'd thy Giant-like conceit; to adde
A suffrage to thy fathers merit, speake?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, heare me: were there not a Chronicle
Well pend by all their tongues, who can report
What they have seene you do; or had you not
Best in your owne performance writ yourselfe,
And been your own Text, I would undertake
Alone, without the helpe of Art, or Character,
But only to recount you deeds in Armes,
And you should ever then be fam'd a president
Of living victory: But as you are
Great, and well worthy to be stiled great,
It would betray a povertie of spirit
In me to obstruct my fortunes, or discent,
If I should coward-like surrender up
The interest, which the inheritance of your vertue,
And mine owne thriftie fate can claime in honour:
My Lord, of all the masse of fame, which any
That weares a sword, and hath but seen me fight,
Gives me, I will not share, nor yeild one jot,
One tittle.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Not to me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are my father,
Yet not to you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ambitious boy, how darst thou
To tell me, that thou wilt contend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Had I
Been sloathfull, and not followed you in all
The streights of death, you might have justly then
Reputed me a bastard; 'tis a cruelty,
More then to murther Innocents, to take
The life of my yet Infant-honour from me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Antinous, looke upon this badge of age,
Thy fathers gray-hair'd beard: full fifty yeares,
(And more then halfe of this, ere thou wert borne)
I have been knowne a Souldier, in which time
I found no difference 'twixt War and Peace,
For War was peace to me, and Peace was war;
Antinous, marke me well; there hath not liv'd
These fifty yeares, a man whom Creet prefer'd
Before thy farher; let me boldly boast,
Thy father, both for Discipline, and Action,
Hath so long been the first of all his Nation;
Now canst thou thinke it honest, charitable,
Nay humane, being so young, my son, my child,
Begot, bred, taught by me, by me thy father,
For one dayes service, and that on thy first,
To rob me of a glory which I fought for
A halfe of hundred yeares.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My case observes
Both equity, and presidents; for sir,
That very day whereon you got your fame,
You tooke it from some other, who was then
Chiefe in repute, as you are now; and had been
Perhaps as many yeares deserving that,
Which you gain'd in a day, as I have mine.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: But he was not my father then Antinous.
Thou leav'st out that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir had he been your father,
He had been then immortall: for a father
Heightens his reputation, where his son
Inherits it, as when you give us life,
Your life is not diminish'd, but renew'd
In us, when you are dead, and we are still
Your living Images.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: So be thou curs'd
In thy posterity, as I in thee,
Dishonorable boy: O shall that Sun,
Which not a yeare yet since, beheld me mounted
Upon a fierie steed, waving my sword,
And teaching this young-man to manage Armes,
That was a raw, fresh novice in the feates
Of Chivalrie, shall that same sun be witnesse
Against this brat, of his ingratitude?
Who to ecclipse the light of my renowne,
Can no way hope to get a Noble name,
But by the treading on his fathers greatnesse;
Thou wilt not yeald? Enter Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My life, but not the prize
My Sword hath purchas'd.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The Senate
My Lord are here at hand; and all the souldiers
Begin to throng about them.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Now Arcanes the—

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Trifles will affront us: that
Fine fighting Stripling,

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Let him have the shame on't:
Please you withdraw on this side.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My great heart
Was never quaild before.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My Lord be confident,
Let not your father dant you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Decius, whether
Must I withdraw?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: On this side.— See the Souldiers
Attend your pleasure— courage sir; the Senate.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Way for the Senate.
sp.stage: Enter Porphicio, Possenme (3 Senators) Gonzalo, Gaspero, Souldiers..
sp.l: My good Lords I know not
What taxe of arrogance I may incurre,
Should I presume, though courted by your favours,
To take a place amongst you: I had rather
Give proofe of my unfeign'd humility
By force, though meane, yet more becomming place,
Then run the hazard of a doubtfull censure.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: My Lord, your wisedome is both known & try'd;
We cannot ranke ye in a nobler friendship,
Then your great service to the state deserves.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Wil't please you sit? Enter Fernando with Sold.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What here my Lord Porphicio?
It must not be.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: My Lord you are too modest.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: It is no season to be troublesome,
Else— But I have done: Your Lordships are observ'd.

sp.speaker: Gosp.
sp.l: Is the demandant ready?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: He is ready.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Produce him then.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Before this sacred presence,
I, by a generall consent, am made
The Souldiers voice, and to your gratious wisedomes,
Present as chiefe in Armes, his Countries Champion,
Cassilanes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Most reverend Lords, you heare the lesser number
Of those who have been Guardians to this Countrey,
Approve this Champion; I in all their names
Who fought for Candy, here present before you
The mightiest man in Armes, Antinous.
Speak fellow souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Antinous, Antinous.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Stand by all, save the two competitors.

sp.speaker: Poss.
sp.l: My Lords, how much your Countrey owes you both,
The due reward of your desertfull glories
Must to posterity remain: But yet
Since, by our Law, one onely can make claime
To the proposed honours which you both
(It seems) have truely merited, take leave
Freely to plead your rights: we shall attend you.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Wherein priority of voyce is granted
Lord Cassilanes to you: for that your rare
And long experience in the course of war,
As well doth challenge it, as the best priviledge
Of Order and civility, for that
You are your brave opponents worthy father.
Say Countrey-men, are you content?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: I, I.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Right grave, right gratious fathers; how unfit
It is for me, that all my life time have
Been practis'd in the schoole of bloud, and slaughter,
To bandy words now in my lifes last farewell,
Your wisedomes will consider; were there pitcht
Another, and another field, like that
Which not yet three days since, this arme hath scatter'd,
Defeated, and made nothing, then the man
That had a heart to thinke he could but follow,
(For equall me he should not) through the lanes
Of danger and amazement, might in that,
That onely of but folowing me, be happy,
Reputed worthy to be made my rivall:
For 'tis not Lords, unknowne to those about me,
(My fellow souldiers) first with what a confidence
I led them on to fight, went on still, and
And as if I could have beene a second Nature,
As well in heartning them by my example,
As by my exhortation, I gave life
To quicken courage, to inflame revenge,
To heighten resolution; in a word,
To out-doe action: It boots not to discover,
How that yong-man, who was not fledg'd nor skil'd
In Martiall play, was even as ignorant
As childish: But I list not to disparage
His non ability: The signall given
Of Battaile, when our enemies came on,
(Directed more by fuerie, then warrant
Of Policy and Stratagem) I met them,
I in the fore-front of the Armies met them;
And as if this old weather-beaten body
Had been compos'd of Cannon-proof, I stood
The volleys of their shot. I, I my selfe
Was he that first dis-rankt their woods of Pikes:
But when we came to handy-stroaks, as often
As I lent blowes, so often I gave wounds,
And every wound a death. I may be bold
To justifie a truth, this very sword
Of mine slew more then any twaine besides:
And, which is not the least of all my glorie,
When he, this young man, hand to hand in fight,
Was by the Generall of the Venetians,
And such as were his retinue, unhors'd,
I stept between, and rescu'd him my selfe,
Or horses hoofs had trampled him to dirt;
And whilst he was re-mounting, I maintain'd
The combate with the gallant Generall,
Till having taken breath, he throng'd before me,
Renew'd the fight, and with a fatall blow,
Stole both that honour from me, and his life
From him, whom I before my selfe alone,
Had more then full three quarters kill'd: A man
Well worthy onely by this hand to have dy'd,
Not by a Boyes weak push: I talke too much,
But 'tis a fault of Age: If to bring home
Long peace, long victorie, even to your Capitoll;
If to secure your Kingdome, Wives, and Children,
Your lives and liberties; if to renowne
Your honours through the world, to fix your names,
Like Blazing starres, admir'd, and fear'd by all,
That have but heard of Candy, or a Cretane,
Be to deserve the approvement of my man-hood,
Then thus much have I done: what more, examine
The Annalls of my life; and then consider
What I have been, and am. Lords I have said.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: With reverence to the Senate, is it lawfull,
Without your Customes breach, to say a word?

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Say on my Lord Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I have heard,
And with no little wonder, such high deeds
Of Chivalrie discours'd, that I confesse,
I doe not think the Worthies while they liv'd
All nine, deserv'd as much applause, or memorie,
As this one: But who can doe ought to gaine
The Crowne of honour from him, must be somewhat
More then a man; you tread a dangerous path,
Yet I shall heare you gladly: for believe me,
Thus much let me professe, in honours cause,
I would not to my father, nor my King,
(My Countries father) yield: if you transcend
What we have heard, I can but onely say,
That miracles are yet in use. I feare
I have offended.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: You have spoken nobly.
Antinous use your priviledge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Princely fathers.
E're I begin, one suit I have to make,
'Tis just, and honourable.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Poss. Speak, and have it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That you would please the souldiers might all stand
Together by their Generall.

sp.speaker: Poss.
sp.l: 'Tis granted.
All fall to yonder side: Goe on, Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall be briefe and plaine: All what my father
(This Countries Patron) hath discours'd, is true.
Fellowes in Armes: speak you is't true?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It followes, that the blaze of my performance
Took light from what I saw him doe; and thus
A City (though the flame be much more dreadfull)
May from a little sparke be set on fire;
Of all what I have done, I shall give instance
Onely in three maine proofs of my desert.
First I sought out (but through how many dangers
My Lords judge ye) the chiefe, the great Commander,
The head of that huge body, whose prowd weight
Our Land shrunke under, him I found and fought with,
Fought with, and slew. Fellowes in Armes, speak you,
Is't true or not?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When he was falne,
The hearts of all our adversaries
Began to quaile, till young Fernando, sonne
To the last Duke of Venice gather'd head,
And soone renew'd the field, by whose example
The bold Venetians doubling strength and courage
Had got the better of the day, our men
Supposing that their adversaries grew
Like Hydra's head, recoyle, and 'gan to slye:
I follow'd them; and what I said, they know;
The summe on't is; I call'd them back, new rankt them;
Lead on, they follow'd, shrunk not till the end:
Fellowes in Armes is't true, or no.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lastly, to finish all, there was but one,
The onely great exploit; which was to take
Fernando prisoner, and that hand to hand
In single fight I did: my selfe without
The helpe of any arme, save the arme of heaven.
Speak souldiers, is it true, or no?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Antinous, Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Behold my prisoner, Fathers.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: This one man
Ruin'd our Army, and hath glorifi'd
Creete in her robes of mightinesse and conquest.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: We need not use long circumstance of words,
Antinous thou art conquerer: the Senate,
The souldiers, and thy valour have pronounc'd it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Antinous, Antinous.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Please ye (my Lord) give leave
That I may part.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: No Cassilanes, the Court
Should therein be dishonour'd, doe not imagine
We prize your presence at so slight a rate.
Demand Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus (my Lords) to witnesse
How far I am from arrogance, or thinking
I am more valiant, though more favour'd
Then my most matchlesse father, my demand is,
That for a lasting memorie of his name,
His deeds, his reall, nay his royall worth,
You set up in your Capitoll in Brasse
My fathers Statue, there to stand for ever
A Monument and Trophy of his victories,
With this Inscription to succeeding ages,
Great Cassilanes, Patron of Candy's Peace,
Perpetuall Triumpher.

sp.speaker: Por. Pos.
sp.l: It is granted. What more?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How boy?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thou art immortall,
Both for thy Son-like pietie, and beauties
Of an unconquer'd minde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Prisoner (Lords)
To your more sacred wisedomes I surrender:
Fit you his ransome; halfe whereof I give
For largesse to the Souldiers: the other halfe
To the erection of this monument.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Ambitious villaine.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thou art all un-immitable.
My Lords to work a certaine peace for Candy
With Venice, use Fernando like a Prince;
His ransome Ile disburse what e're it be:
Yet you may stay him with you, till conditions
Of amitie shall be concluded on:
Are yee content?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: We are, and ever rest
Both friends add debters to your noblenesse.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Souldiers attend me in the Market-place,
Ile thither send your largesse.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Antinous, Antinous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I have a sute too, Lords.

sp.speaker: Porp. Pos.
sp.l: Propose it, 'tis yours, if fit and just.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Let not my services,
My being forty yeares a drudge, a pack-horse
To you, and to the State, be branded now
With Ignominy ne're to be forgotten:
Reare me no Monument, unlesse you meane
To have me fam'd a Coward, and be stamp'd so.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: We understand you not.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Proud boy, thou dost,
And Tyrant-like insult'st upon my shame.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, heaven can tell, and my integrity,
What I did, was but onely to inforce
The Senates gratitude. I now acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Observe it Fathers, how this haughty boy
Growes cunning in his envy of mine honours:
He knowes no mention can of me be made,
But that it ever likewise must be told,
How I by him was master'd; and for surety
That all succeeding times may so report it,
He would have my dishonour, and his Triumphs
Ingrav'd in Brasse: hence, hence proceeds the falshood
Of his insinuating piety.
Thou art no childe of mine: thee and thy bloud,
Here in the Capitoll, before the Senate,
I utterly renounce: So thrift and fate
Confirme me; henceforth never see my face,
Be, as thou art, a villaine to thy father.
Lords I must crave your leaves: come, come Arcanes. Ex.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Here's a strange high-borne spirit.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Tis but heat
Of suddaine present rage; I dare assure
Antinous of his favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I not doubt it,
He is both a good man, and a good father.
I shall attend your Lordships.

sp.speaker: Poss.
sp.l: Doe Antinous.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes: feast thy Triumphs,
With applause and pleasures.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Poss. Lead on. Exeunt. Flor. Cornets.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I utterly renounce— 'Twas so?
Was't not, my Decius?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Pish, you know my Lord,
Old men are chollerick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And lastly parted
With, never henceforth see my face: O me,
How have I lost a Father? Such a father?
Such a one Decius! I am miserable,
Beyond expression.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Fie, how unbecomming
This shewes upon your day of fame?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O mischiefe:
I must no more come neare him; that I know,
And am assur'd on't.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Say you doe not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: True:
Put case I doe not: what is Candy then
To lost Antinous? Malta, I resolve
To end my dayes in thee.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile trie
All humble meanes of being reconcil'd,
Which if deny'd, then I may justly say,
This day has prov'd my worst: Decius my worst. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: NOw to what you have heard; as no man can
Better then I, give you her Character;
For I have been both nurs'd, and traind up to
Her petulant humours, and been glad to beare them,
Her brother, my late Master, did no lesse:
Strong apprehensions of her beauty hath
Made her believe that she is more then woman:
And as there did not want those flatterers
'Bout the worlds Conquerour, to make him think,
And did perswade him that he was a god;
So there be those base flies, that will not stick
To buzze into her eares she is an Angel,
And that the food she feeds on is Ambrosia.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She should not touch it then, 'tis Poets fare.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I may take leave to say, she may as well
Determine of her selfe to be a goddesse,
With lesser flatterie then he a god:
For she does conquer more, although not farther.
Every one looks on her dyes in despaire,
And would be glad to doe it actually,
To have the next age tell how worthily,
And what good cause he had to perish so:
Her beauty is superlative, she knowes it,
And knowing it, thinks no man can deserve,
But ought to perish, and to dye for her:
Many great Princes for her love have languish'd,
And given themselves a willing sacrifice,
Proud to have ended so: And now there is
A Prince so manded in his owne passions,
That he forgets the Royaltie he was borne to,
And deems it happinesse to be her slave.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You talke as if you meant to winde me in,
And make me of the number.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Sir, mistake me not, the service that I owe ye
Shall plead for me: I tell you what she is,
What she expects, and what she will effect,
Unlesse you be the miracle of men,
That come with a purpose to behold,
And goe away your selfe.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I thanke you, I will doe it: But pray resolve me,
How is the stor'd with wit?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: As with beauty,
Infinite, and more to be admired at,
Then medled with.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And walks her tongue the same gate with her feet?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Much beyond: what ere her heart thinks, she utters:
And so bold, so readily, as you would judge
It penn'd and studied.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.p: She comes. Enter Erota, Philander, Annophill, Hyparcha, Mochingo, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I must leave you then,
But my best wishes shall remain with you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Still I must thanke you.
This is the most passionate,
Most pitifull Prince,
Who in the Caldron of affections,
Looks as he had been par-boyl'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I offend with too much loving you,
It is a fault that I must still commit,
To make your mercy shine the more on me.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: You are the selfe-same creature you condemne,
Or else you durst not follow me with hope
That I can pittie you, who am so farre
From granting any comfort in this kinde,
That you and all men else shall perish first:
I will live free and single, till I finde
Something above a man to equall me;
Put all your brave Heroes into one,
Your Kings and Emperours, and let him come
In person, of a man, and I should scorne him:
Must, and will scorne him.
The god of Love himselfe hath lost his eyes,
His Bow and Torch extinguish'd, and the Poets
That made him first a god, have lost their fire
Since I appear'd, and from my eyes must steale it.
This I dare speak; and let me see the man,
Now I have spoke it, that doth, dare deny;
Nay, not believe it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: He is mad that does not.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Have not all the nations of the earth heard of me?
Most come to see me, and seeing me, return'd
Full of my praises? teaching there Chroniclers
To make their Stories perfect? for where the name,
Meerely the word of faire Erota stands,
It is a lasting History to time,
Begetting admiration in the men,
And in my owne Sex envie; which glorie's lost,
When I shall stick my beautie in a cloud,
And clearely shine through it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: This Woman's in the altitudes, and he must be
A good Astrologer shall know her Zodiack.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For any man to thinke
Himselfe an able purchaser of you,
But in the bargaine there must be declar'd
Infinite bounty: otherwise I vow,
By all that's excellent and gracious in you,
I would untenant every hope lodg'd in me,
And yield my selfe up Loves, or your owne Martyr.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: So you shall please us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O you cannot be
So heavenly, and so absolute in all things,
And yet retaine such cruell tyranny.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: I can, I doe, I will.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She is in her
Moods, and her Tences: Ile Gramer with you,
And make a triall how I can decline you:
By your leave (great Lady.)

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: A man, a good man, that's a wealthy;
A Proper man, and a proud man too; one
That understands himselfe, and knowes, unlesse
It be your self, no woman on the Universe deserves him.
Nay, Lady, I must tell you too withall.
I may make doubt of that, unlesse you paint
With better judgement next day then on this;
For (plaine I must be with you) 'tis a dull Fucus.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Knowes any one here what this fellow is?

sp.speaker: Attend.
sp.l: He is of Venice (Madam) a great Magnifico,
And gracious with the Senate.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Let him keep then among them; what makes he here?
Here's state enough where I am: here's a doe—
You, tell him, if he have ought with us, let him
Look lower, and give it in Petition.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Mighty Magnifico, my Mistris bid me tell you,
If you have ought with her, you must look lower,
And yeeld it in Petition.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Here is for thee a Ducket.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You say well sir, take your owne course.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I will not grace you
(Lady) so much as take you by the hand;
But when I shall vouchsafe to touch your lip,
It shall be through your Court a holy-day
Proclamed for so high favour.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: This is some
Great mans Jester: Sirrah, begone, here is
No place to foole in.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Where are the fooles you talke of?
I doe keep two.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: No question of it: for
In your selfe you doe maintaine an hundred.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And besides them I keep a noble traine,
Statists, and men of action: my purse is large and deep,
Beyond the reach of riot to draw drie:
Fortune did vie with Nature, to bestow
(When I was borne) her bountie equally:
Tis not amisse you turne your eyes from me;
For should you stand and gaze me in the face,
You perish would, like Semele by Iolus:
In Venice at this instant there do lye
No lesse then threescore Ladies in their graves,
And in their Beds five hundred for my love.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: You lie more then they; yet it becomes him bravely;
Would I could walke and talke so? Ile endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, doe you know me?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Yes, you were sister to the late Prince of Candy,
Aunt to this young one: And I in Venice,
I am borne a Lord; equall to you in fortunes,
In shape; Ile say no more, but view.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: There needs no more be said, were I a woman—
O he does rarely: in shape; Ile say no more,
But view: Who could say more, who better?
Man is no man, nor woman woman is,
Unlesse they have a pride like one of these.
How poore the Prince of Cyprus shewes to him?
How poore another Lady unto her:
Carriage and State makes us seem demi-gods,
Humility, like beasts, wormes of the earth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Royall Lady, I kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, I know you not.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: O my noble Brother, welcome from the wars.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Deare sister.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Where is my father, that you come without him?
We have news of your successe: he has his health I hope?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes sister, he has his health, but is not well.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: How not well? what Riddles do you utter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile tell you more in private.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Noble sir,
I cannot be unmindfull of your merit,
Since I last heard it: you are a hopefull youth,
And (indeed) the soule of Candy.
I must speak my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: The Prince of Cyprus Brother, Good Decius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am his servant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You are the Patron of your Countrie, sir,
So your unimitable deeds proclame you,
It is no language of my owne, but all mens.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Your Enemies must needs acknowledge it:
Then doe not thinke it flatterie in your friends,
For if they had a heart, they could not want a tongue.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Is this your brother Annophill?

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Your name's Antinous?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am (Lady) that most unfortunate man.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: How unfortunate? are you not the souldier,
The Captaine of those Captaines, that did bring
Conquest and victory home along with you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had some share in't; but was the least
Of the least worthy.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O sir, in your modesty youl'd make
A double Conquest: I was an eare-witnesse
When this young man spoke lesser then he acted,
And had the souldiers voice to helpe him out:
But that the Law compell'd him for his honour,
To inforce him make a claime for his reward,
I well perceive he would have stood the man
That he does now, buried his worth in silence.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, I hearken not to him, but looke on you,
And finde more in you then he can relate?
You shall attend on me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Deny it not sir, for it is more honour
Then you have gotten ith' field: for know you shall,
Upon Erota's asking, serve Erota.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I may want answers, Lady,
But never want a will to doe you service.
I came here to my sister, to take leave,
Having enjoyn'd my selfe to banishment,
For some cause that hereafter you may heare,
And wish with me I had not the occasion.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: There shall be no occasion to divide us:
Deare Madam for my sake use your power,
Even for the service that he ought to owe,
Must, and does owe to you, his friends, and countrey.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Upon your Loyalty to the state and me,
I doe command you Sir, not depart Candy:
Am I not your Princesse?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are a great Lady.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Then shew your selfe a Servant and a Subject.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am your vassaile.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You are a Coward; I that dare not fight,
Scorne to be vassaile to any Prince in Europe:
Great is my heart with pride, which Ile encrease
When they are gone, with practise on my Vassailes.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.l: The noble Cassilane is come to see you Madam,

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: There's comfort in those words, Antinous:
For here's the place, and persons that have power,
To reconcile you to his love againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That were a fortunate meeting.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Greatnesse still wait you Lady.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good Cassilane, we doe maintain our greatnesse,
Through your valour.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My prayers pull dayly blessings on thy head,
My un-offending childe, my Annophill.
Good Prince, worthy Gonzalo! ha? art thou here
Before me? in every action art thou ambitious?
My duty (Lady) first offered here,
And love to thee (my childe) though he out-strip me;
Thus in the wars he got the start on me,
By being forward, but performing lesse;
All the endeavours of my life are lost,
And throwne upon that evill of mine owne
Cursed begetting, whom I shame to father.
O that the heat thou robd'st me off, had burnt
Within my Entrailes, and begot a feaver,
Or some worse sicknesse, for thou art a disease
Sharper then any physick gives a name to.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Why doe you say so?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O Annophill; there is good cause my girle:
He has plaid the thiefe with me, and filch'd away
The richest jewell of my life, my honour,
Wearing it publikely with that applause,
As if he justly did inherit it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would I had in my Infancy been laid
Within my grave, covered with you blessings,
Then growne up to a man, to meet your curses.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O that thou hadst.
Then I had been the father of a childe,
Dearer then thou wert even unto me,
When hope perswaded me I had begot
Another selfe in thee: Out of mine eyes,
As farre as I have throwne thee from my heart,
That I may live and dye forgetting thee.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: How has he deserv'd this untam'd anger,
That when he might have ask't for his reward
Some honour for himselfe, or masse of pelfe,
He onely did request to have erected
Your Statue in the Capitoll, with Titles
Ingrav'd upon't, The Patron of his Countrey?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: That, that's the poison in the gilded cup,
The Serpent in the flowers, that stings my honour,
And leaves me dead in fame: Gods doe a justice,
And rip his bosome up, that men may see,
Seeing, believe the subtle practises
Written within his heart: But I am heated,
And doe forget this presence, and my selfe.
Your pardon, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: You should not aske, 'lesse you knew how to give.
For my sake Cassilane, cast out of your thoughts
All ill conceptions of your worthy son,
That (questionlesse) has ignorantly offended,
Declared in his penitence.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Bid me dye (Lady) for your sake Ile doe it;
But that you'll say is nothing, for a man
That has out-liv'd his honour: But command me
In any thing save that, and Cassilane
Shall ever be your servant. Come Annophill,
(My joy in this world) thou shalt live with me,
Retired in some sollitarie nook,)
The comfort of my age; my dayes are short,
And ought to be well spent: and I desire
No other witnesse of them but thy selfe,
And good Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: I shall obey you sir.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Noble sir:
If you taste any want of worldly meanes
Let not that discontent you: know me your friend,
That hath, and can supply you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir, I am too much bound to you already,
And 'tis not of my cares the least, to give you
Faire satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You may imagine I doe speak to that end,
But trust me, 'tis to make you bolder with me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke you, and may make triall of you,
Meane time my service.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Brother be comforted; so long as I continue
Within my fathers love, you cannot long
Stand out an Exile: I must goe live with him,
And I will prove so good an Orator
In your behalfe, that you againe shall gaine him,
Or I will stirre in him another anger,
And be lost with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Better I were neglected: for he is hasty,
And through the Choller that abounds in him,
(Which for the time divides from him his judgement)
He may cast you off, and with you his life;
For griefe will strait surprize him, and that way
Must be his death: the sword has try'd too often,
And all the deadly Instruments of warre
Have aim'd at his great heart, but ne're could touch it:
Yet not a limbe about him wants a scarre.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Madam my duty—

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will you he gone?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I must (Lady) but I shall be ready,
When you are pleas'd command me, for your service.
Excellent Prince— To all my heartie love,
And a good farewell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thanks honest Cassilane.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Come Annophill.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Shall I not wait upon you sir?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: From hence you shall not stirre a foot:
Loving Gonzalo, it must be all my study
To requite you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I may be so fortunate to deserve
The name of friend from you, I have enough.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: You are so, and you have made your selfe so.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I will then preserve it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Antinous you are my servant, are you not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It hath pleased you so to grace me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Why are you then dejected? you will say,
You have lost a father; but you have found a Mistris
Doubles that losse: be master of your spirit;
You have a cause for it.: which is my favour,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will no man ease me of this foole?

sp.speaker: Gonz:
sp.l: Your fellow.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Antinous wait upon us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall Madam.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Nay but Ladie, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Sir, you are rude: and if you be the Master
Of such meanes as you doe talk of, you should
Learne good manners.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O Lady, you can finde a fault in me,
But not perceive it in your selfe; you must, shall heare me:
I love you for your pride, 'tis the best vertue
In you.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: I could hang this fellow now: by whom
Are you supported, that you dare doe this?
Have you not example here in a Prince
Transcending you in all things, yet beares himselfe
As doth become a man had seen my beautie?
Back to your Countrey, and your Curtizans,
Where you may be admired for your wealth,
Which being consum'd, may be a meanes to gaine you
The opinion of some wit. Here's nothing
To be got but scorne, and losse of time.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Which are things I delight in.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Antinous follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She is vext to the soule.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Let her be vext, 'tis fit she should be so:
Give me thy hand Gonzalo, thou art in our favour,
For we doe love to cherish lofty spirits,
Such as percusteere the earth, and bound
With an erected countenance to the clouds.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'S-foot, what thing is this?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I doe love fire-works, because they mount:
An Exhalation I professe to adore,
Beyond a fixed starre, 'tis more illustrious,
As every thing rais'd out of smoak is so:
Their vertue is in action: what doe you think of me?

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: Troth sir,
You are beyond my ghesse, I know you not.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Doe you know your selfe?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why you and I are one: I am proud, and
Very proud too, that I must tell you; I saw
It did become you, cousin Gonzalo, prethee
Let it be so.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Let it be so good cousin.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am no great ones foole.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I hope so, for alliance sake.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Yet I do serve the Mighty, Monstrous, and Magnanimous
Invincible Erota.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O good cousin, now I have you: Ile meet you in your Coat.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Coat? I have my horse-mans coat I must confesse
Lin'd through with Velvet, and a Scarlet out-side;
If you'll meet me in't, Ile send fort;
And cousin you shall see me with much comfort,
For it is both a new one, and a right one,
It did not come collaterall.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Adieu good cousin; at this present I have some businesse.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Farewell (excellent cousin.)

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: CAndy, I say, is lost already.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes,
If to be conqueror be to be lost.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You have it; one dayes conquest hath undone them,
And sold them to their vassalage; for what
Have I else toyl'd my braines, profusely emptied
My moneyes, but to make them slaves to Venice,
That so in case the sword did lose his edge,
Then Art might sharpen hers?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gonzalo how?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Fernando thus: you see how through this Land,
Both of the best and basest I am honour'd;
I onely gave the State of Venice notice,
When, where, and how to land, or you had found
A better entertainment: I was he
Encourag'd young Antinous to affront
The devill his father: for the devill I think
Dares not doe more in battaile.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But why did ye?
I finde no such great policie in that.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Indeed Fernando, thou canst fight, not plot:
Had they continu'd one, they two alone
Were of sufficient courage and performance
To beat an Armie.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Now by all my hopes,
I rather shall admire, then envy vertue.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why then by all your hopes you'll rather have
Your Braines knockt out, then learne how to be wise;
You States-man? Well sir, I did more then this,
When Cassilane crav'd from the common treasure
Pay for his Souldiers, I strook home, and lent him
An hundred thousand Duckets,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Marry sir,
The policy was little, the love lesse,
And honesty least of all.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: How say ye by that?
Go fight, I say goe fight, Ile talke no more with you,
You are insensible.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, I shall observe ye,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why look you sir, by this meanes have I got
The greatest part of Cassilanes estate
Into my hands, which he can ne're redeem,
But must of force sinke: do you conceive me now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So:
But why have you importuned the Senate,
For me to sojourne with them?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: There's the quintessence,
The soule, and grand elixer of my wit:
For he (according to his noble nature)
Will not be knowne to want, though he do want,
And will be bankrupted so much the sooner,
And made the subject of our scorne and laughter.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Here's a perfect plotted stratagem.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why? could you
Imagine, that I did not hate in heart
My Countreyes enemies? yes, yes, Fernando,
And I will be the man that shall undoe them.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ye are in a ready way.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I was never out on't.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Peace,
Here comes a wise Coxcombe, a tame Coward.
Now worthy Gaspero, what,
You come (I know) to be my Lord Fernando's
Conducter to old Cassilane?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: To wait upon him.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And my Lords the Senators sent you?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: My noble Lord they did.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My Lord Fernando,
This gentleman (as humble as you see him)
Is even this Kingdomes treasure; In a word,
'Tis his chiefe glory that he is not wiser
Then honest, nor more honest then approv'd
In truth and faith.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You may be bold
To trust him with your bosome, he'll not deceive,
If you relie upon him once.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Your name is Gaspero?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Goe commend me
(Right honest Gaspero) commend me heartily
To noble Cassilane, tell him my love
Is vow'd to him.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I know you will.
My Lord I cannot long be absent from you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, you are now my guide. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Thus my designes
Run uncontroul'd; yet Venice though I be
Intelligencer to thee, in my braine
Are other large Projects: for if proud Erota
Bend to my lure, I will be Candy's King,
And Duke of Venice too. Ha? Venice too?
O 'twas prettily shov'd in: why not? Erota
May in her love seale all sure: if she swallow
The bait, I am Lord of both; if not, yet Candy
Despight of all her power shall be ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Urge me no farther Annophill.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Thy fathers poverty has made thee happie;
For though 'tis true, this solitary life
Sutes not with youth and beautie, O my childe,
Yet 'tis the sweetest Guardian to protect
Chaste names from Court-aspersions; there a Lady.
Tender and delicate in yeares and graces,
That doats upon the charmes of ease and pleasure,
Is ship-wrackt on the shore; for 'tis much safer
To trust the Ocean in a leaking ship,
Then follow greatnesse in the wanton rites
Of luxurie and sloth.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My wishes sir,
Have never soar'd a higher flight, then truely
To finde occasion wherein I might witnesse
My duty and obedience.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: 'Tis well said,
Canst thou forbeare to laugh Arcanes?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: To look upon my beggerie, to look upon
My patience in my beggerie: Tell me,
Does it shew handsome? bravely?
Handsome? thou wilt flatter me,
And sweare that I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Nothing
More glorifies the noble, and the valiant,
Then to despise contempt: if you continue
But to enjoy your selfe, you in your selfe
Enjoy all store besides.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: An excellent change:
I that some seven Apprentice-ships commanded
A hundred Ministers, that waited on
My nod, and sometimes twenty thousand souldiers,
Am now retir'd, attended in my age
By one poore maid, followed by one old man.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, you are lower in your owne repute
Then you have reason for.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The Romane Captaines,
I meane the best, such as with their blouds
Purchas'd their Countreyes peace, the Empires glorie,
Were glad at last to get them to some Farmes,
Off-from the clamours of the ingratefull great ones,
And the unsteddy multitude, to live
As I doe now, and 'twas their blessing too,
Let it be ours Arcanes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I cannot but
Applaud your scorne of injuries.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Of injuries?
Arcanes, Annophill, lend both your hands
So, what say yee now?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why now my Lord—

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I sweare
By all my past prosperities; thus standing
Between you two, I thinke my selfe as great,
As mighty, as if in the Capitoll
I stood amidst the Senators, with all
The Cretane subjects prostrate at my feet.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Sir, you are here more safe.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: And more beloved:
Why look yee sirs, I can forget the weaknesse
Of the traduced souldiers, the neglect
Of the faire-spoken Senate, the impietie
Of him, the villaine, whom (to my dishonour)
The World miscalls my son.
But by the—

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, remember that you promis'd no occasion
Should move your patience.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Thou do'st chide me friendly,
He shall not have the honour to be thought upon
Amongst us. Enter a Servant.
Now? the newes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Secretarie,
With the Venetian prisoner, desire
Admittance to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How? to me?
What mysterie is this? Arcanes can they
Thinkst thou, meane any good?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My Lord, they dare not
Intend ought else but good.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Tis true, they dare not;
Arcanes welcome them: Come hither Annophill,
Stand close to me, wee'll change our affability
Into a forme of State: and they shall know
Our heart is still our owne.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Arcanes,
I know them both: Fernando, as you are
A man of greatnesse, I should under-value
The right my sword hath fought for, to observe
Low-fawning complements, but as you are
A Captive and a stranger, I can love you,
And must be kinde. You are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: 'Tis the all
Of my ambition.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: And for proof how much
He truely honours your heroick vertues,
The Senate on his importunity,
Commend him to your Lordships guard.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: During the time of his abode in Candy.
To be your houshold guest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wherein my Lord,
You shall more make me debtor to your noblenesse,
Then if you had return'd me without ransome.

sp.speaker: Cass
sp.l: Are you in earnest Sir?

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: My sute to the Senate
Shall best resolve you that.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Come hither Secretarie,
Look that this be no trick now put upon me:
For if it be— Sirrah.—

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: As I have troth
(My Lord) it onely is a favour granted
Upon Fernando's motion from himselfe:
Your Lordship must conceive, I'de not partake
Ought, but what should concerne your honour; who
Has been the prop, our Countries shield, and safety,
But the renowned Cassilane?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Applause?
Is Gaspero— puffe— nothing— why, young Lord,
Would you so much be sequester'd from those
That are the blazing Comets of the time,
To live a solitarie life with me?
A man forsaken? all my hospitality
Is now contracted to a few; these two,
This tempest wearied souldier, and this Virgin;
We cannot feast your eyes with Masques and Revells,
Or Courtly Anticks: the sad sports we riot in,
Are Tales of foughten fields, of Martiall scarres,
And things done long agoe, when men of courage
Were held the best, not those well-spoken youths,
Who onely carry conquest in their tongues;
Now stories of this nature are unseasonable
To entertaine a great Dukes son with.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Herein
Shall my Captivity be made my happinesse,
Since what I lose in freedome, I regaine
(With int'rest) by conversing with a Souldier
So much lesse for experience, as great Cassilane.
Pray sir admit me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: If you come to mock me,
I shall be angrie.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By the love I beare
To goodnesse, my intents are honourable.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Then in a word, my Lord, your visitations
Shall find all due respect: But I am now
Growne old, and have forgot to be an host;
Come when you please you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Good sir be not too urgent; for my father
Will soon be mov'd: yet in a noble way
Of courtesie he is as easily conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lady, your words are like your beauty, powerfull;
I shall not strive more how to doe him service,
Then how to be your servant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Shee's my daughter,
And does command this house.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I so conceive her.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: My honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Commend me to them.
Tell 'em I thank them.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Whom my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cas
sp.l: The Senate:
Why now come you so dull? O they are gratious,
And infinitely gratefull Thou art eloquent,
Speak modestly in mentioning my services:
And if ought fall out in the By, that must
Of meere necessity touch any act
Of my deserving praises, blush when you talke on't,
'Twill make them blush to heare on't.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Why my Lord—

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you are too wise now; good, observe me,
I doe not raile against the hopefull Springall,
That builds up monuments in Brasse; reares Trophies
With Mottoes and Inscriptions, quaint devices
Of Poetrie and fiction; let's be quiet.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You must not crosse him.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Not for Candys wealth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall for ever make me yours.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: 'Twere pitty to double your captivity.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Who's here, Decius? Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ha! Decius? who nam'd Decius?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My duty to your Lordship: I am bold,
Presuming on your noble and knowne goodnesse
To.—

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Present you with this—

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Letter?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Yes my honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Please you peruse
The in-side, you shall finde a name subscrib'd,
In such humility, in such obedience,
That you your selfe will judge it tyranny
Not to receive it favourably.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hey-day.
Good words my Masters; this is Court-infection,
And none but Cowards ply them: Tell me, Decius,
Without more circumstance, who is the sender?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Your much griev'd sonne Antinous.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: On my life
A challenge; speak, as thou art worthy speak:
Ile answer't.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Honour'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: No honour'd Sirs—
Foole your yong Idoll with such pompous Attributes.
Say briefely, what containes it?

sp.speaker: Dec,
sp.l: 'Tis a lowly
Petition for your favour.

sp.speaker: Cas,
sp.l: Rash young man,
But that thou art under my owne roofe, and know'st
I dare not any way infringe the Lawes
Of hospitality, thou should'st repent
Thy bold and rude intrusion. But presume not
Againe to shew thy Letter, for thy life;
Decius, not for thy life.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Nay then (my Lord)
I can with-hold no longer: you are too rough,
And wrestle against nature, with a violence
More then becomes a father: wherein would yee
Come nearer to the likenesse of God,
Then in your being entreated? Let not thirst
Of honour, make you quite forget you are
A man, and what makes perfect man-hoods, comforts
A father.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: If a memory remaine
Of my departed mother; if the purity
Of her unblemish'd faith deserve to live
In your remembrance, let me yet by these
Awake your love to my uncomforted Brother.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am a stranger: but so much I tender
Your sons desertfull vertues, that I vow
His Sword nere conquer'd me so absolutely,
As shall your curtesie, if you vouchsafe
At 〈◊〉 our instances, to new receive him,
Into your wonted favour.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Sir, you cannot
Require more low submission.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Am I not
Growne vile yet in your eyes? then by the name
Of father, let me once more sue for him,
Who is the only now remaining-branch
With me, of that most ancient roote, whose body
You are, deare sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: 'Tis well: an host of furies
Could not have baited me, more torturingly,
More rudely, or more most unnaturally?
Decius, I say, let me no more heare from him;
For this time goe thou hence, and know from me
Thou art beholding to me that I have not
Killed thee already, looke to't next, looke to't.
Arcanes fie, fie Annophil, Exit.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: He's gone.
Chaf'd beyond sufferance: we must follow him.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Lady, this letter is to you.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Come with me,
For we must speake in private: please you sir,
To see what entertainement our sad house
Can yeild? Ex.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I shall attend you Lady.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: How do ye like
To sojourne here, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: More then to feast
With all the Princes of the earth besides;
Gonzalo told me that thou wert honest.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Yes sir.
And you shall find it.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Shall I?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: All my follies
Be else recorded to my shame.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Enough,
My heart is here for ever lodg'd.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: The Lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The place admits no time to utter all,
But Gaspero if thou wilt prove my friend,
I'le say thou art—

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Your servant: I conceive ye,
Wee'll choose some fitter leisure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Never man
Was (in a moment) or more bless'd, or wretched. Exeunt.
sp.stage: Enter Hyparcha, (placing two chaires) Antinous, and Erota.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Hy.
sp.l: I shall. Ex.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous sit downe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam:

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I say sit downe: I do command you sit;
For looke what honour thou didst gaine by me,
I cannot lose by it: happy Antinous,
The graces, and the higher Deities
Smil'd at thy birth, and still continue it:
Then thinke that I (who scorne lesser examples)
Must doe the like: such as do taste my power,
And talke of it, with feare and reverence,
Shall do the same unto the man I favour.
I tel thee youth, thou hast a conquest won,
Since thou cam'st home, greater then that last,
Which dignified thy same; greater then if
Thou shouldst goe out againe, and conquer farther;
For I am not asham'd to acknowledge
My selfe subdued by thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Great Lady—

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sit still, I will not heare thee else: now speake,
And speake like my Antinous, like my Souldier,
Whom Cupid, and not Mars, hath sent to Battle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must (I see) be silent.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So thou maist:
There's greater Action in it than in clamour,
A looke, (if it be gratious) will begin the War,
A word conclude it: then prove no Coward,
Since thou hast such a friendly enemie,
That teaches thee to conquer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You do amaze me Madam,
I have no skill, no practice in this War,
And whether you be serious, or please
To make your sport on a dejected man,
I cannot rightly ghesse: but be it as it will,
It is a like unhappinesse to me:
My discontents beare those conditions in them, Musick.
And lay me out so wretched, no designes
( How ever truly promising a good)
Can make me rellish ought, but a sweet-bitter,
Voluntarie Exile. Musick againe

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Why an Exile?
What comfort can there be in those companions Enter Hyparcha.
Which sad thoughts bring along with?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Whence comes this well-tun'd sound?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I know not Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Listen wench:
What ever friendly hands they are that send it Song.
Let 'em play on; they are Masters of their facultie.
Doth it please you sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: According to the time.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Go to 'em wench,
And tell 'em, we shall thanke 'em; for they have kept
As good time to our disposition, as to their instruments;
Unlesse Antinous shall say he loves, Enter Philander.
There never can be sweeter accents uttered.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Let then the heart, that did imploy those hands,
Receive some small share of your thankes with them,
'Tis happinesse enough that you did like it;
A fortune unto me, that I should send it
In such a lucky minute; but to obtaine
So gratious welcome, did exceed my hopes.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Good Prince, I thanke you for it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Madam, poure not (to fast) joyes on me,
But sprinkle 'em so gently, I may stand 'em:
It is enough at first, you have laid aside
Those cruell angry lookes out of your eyes,
With which (as with your lovely) you did strike
All your beholders in an Extasie.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Philander, you have long profess'd to love me,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Have I but profest it Madam?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: More attentively, then to an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And I will speake more truly, if more can be:
Nor shall my language be wrapt up in Riddles,
But plaine as truth it selfe: I love this Gentleman,
Whose griefes has made him so uncapable
Of Love, he will not heare, at least not understand it.
I that have lookt with scornefull eyes on thee,
And other Princes mighty in their states,
And in their friends as fortunate, have now prai'd,
In a petitionary kind almost,
This man, this wel deserving man, (that I must say)
To looke upon this beauty, yet you see
He casts his eyes rather upon the ground,
Then he will turne 'em this way; Philander
You looke pale; I'le talke no more.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pray go forward: I would be your Martyr,
To dye thus, were immortally to live.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Will you goe to him then, and speake for me?
You have loved longer, but not ferventer,
Know how to speake, for you have done it like
An Orator, even for your selfe: then how will you for me
Whom you professe to love above your selfe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The curses of dissemblers follow me
Unto my grave, and if I do not so.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You may (as all men do) speake boldlier, better
In their friends cause still, then in your owne;
But speake your utmost, yet you cannot feigne,
I will stand by, and blush to witnesse it.
Tell him since I beheld him, I have lost
The happinesse of this life, food, and rest;
A quiet bosome, and the state I went with.
Tell him how he has humbled the proud,
And made the living but a dead Erota.
Tell him withall, that she is better pleas'd
With thinking on him, then enjoying these.
Tell him— Philander, Prince; I talke in vaine
To you, you do not marke me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Indeed, I do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But thou dost looke so pale,
As thou wilt spoyle the story in relating.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Not, if I can but live to tell it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It may be you have not the heart.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.l: I have a will I am sure, how e're my heart
May play the coward, but if you please, I'le trie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: If a kisse will strengthen thee, I give you leave
To challenge it, nay, I will give it you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O that a man should taste such heavenly blisse!
And be enjoyn'd to beg it for another.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, it is a miserie I grieve
To put you to, and I will suffer rather
In his tyranny, than thou in mine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay Madam, since I cannot have your love,
I will endeavour to deserve your pitty:
For I had rather have within the grave
Your love, then you should want it upon earth.
But how can I hope, with a feeble tongue
To instruct him in the rudiments of love,
When your most powerfull beauty cannot worke it?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt (Philander) the request
Is so unreasonable, that I quit thee of it.
I desire now no more, but the true patience,
And fortitude of Lovers, with those helpes
Of sighes and teares, which I think is all the Phisick—

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O if he did but heare you, 'twere enough;
And I will wake him from his Appoplexie.
Antinous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay pray,
No curtesie to me, you are my Lord,
(Indeed you are) for you command her heart,
That commands mine: nor can you want to know it.
For looke you she that told it you in words,
Explaines it now more passionately in teares;
Either thou hast no heart, or a marble one,
If those drops cannot melt it; prethee looke up,
And see how sorrow sits within her eyes,
And love the griefe she goes with (if not her)
Of which thou art the parent: and never yet
Was there (by nature) that thing made so stony,
But it would love what ever it begot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He that begot me, did beget these cares
Which are good issues, though happily by him
Esteemed monsters: nay, the ill-judging world
Is likely enough to give them those Characters.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What's this to love, and to love, and to the Lady? he's old,
Wrathfull, perverse, selfe-will'd, and full of anger,
Which are his faults; but let them not be thine;
He thrusts you from his love, she puls thee on,
He doubts your vertues, she doth double them:
O either use thy owne eyes, or take mine,
And with them, my heart, then thou wilt love her,
Nay, doate upon her, more then on thy duty,
And men will praise thee equally for it;
Neglecting her, condemne thee, as a man
Unworthy such a fortune: O Antinous,
'Tis not the friendship that I beare to thee,
But her command, that makes me utter this:
And when I have prevail'd, let her but say,
Philander, you must dye or this is nothing,
It shall be done together with a breath,
With the same willingnesse, I live to serve her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No more Philander.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: All I have done, is little yet to purpose,
But ere I leave him, I will perceive him blush;
And make him feele the passions that I do,
And every true lover will assist me in't,
And lend me their sad sighs to blow it home,
For Cupid wants a dart to wound this bosome.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No more, no more Philander, I can endure no more,
Pray let him goe; go good Antinous, make peace
With your owne mind, no matter though I perish. Ex.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I Cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Nor do I require it,
The malady needs no Phisitian,
Helpe hospitall people.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I am glad to heare
You are so valliant.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Valiant?
Can any man be proud that is not valiant;
Foolish woman, what wouldst thou say? thou—
I know not what to call thee.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: I can you,
For I can call you Coxcome, Asse, and Puppy.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: You do do it, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: That you'l lose a fortune,
Which a Cobler better deserves, then thou dost.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Do not provoke my magnanimity,
For when I am insens'd, I am insensible;
Go tell thy Lady, that hath sent me word
She will discard me, that I discard her,
And throw a scorne upon her, which I would not,
But that she does me wrong.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you not glory in your conquest more,
To take some great man prisoner, then to kill him?
And shall a Lady find lesse mercie from you,
That yeilds her selfe your Captive, and for her Ransome,
Will give the jewell of her life, her heart,
Which she hath lockt from all men but thy selfe:
For shame (Antinous) throw this dulnesse off,
Art thou a man no where but in the field?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: He must here Drums, and Trumpets ere he sleeps,
And at this instant dreames he's in his Armour:
These Iron-hearted Souldiers are so cold,
Till they be beaten to a womans armes,
And then they love 'em better then their owne;
No Fort can hold them out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What pitty is it (Madam) that your selfe,
Who are all excellence, should become so wretched,
To thinke on such a wretch as griefe hath made me?
Seldom despairing men looke up to heaven,
Although it still speake to 'em in its glories;
For when sad thoughts perplexe the mind of man,
There is a plumit in the heart, that waighs,
And puls us (living) to the dust we came from;
Did you but see the miseries you pursue,
(As I the happinesse that I avoid
That doubles my afflictions) you would flye
Unto some wildernesse, or to your grave,
And there find better comforts then in me,
For love, and cares can never dwell together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: They should,
If thou hadst but my love, and I thy cares.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What wild beast in the Desart, but would be
Taught by this Tongue to leave his crueltie,
Though all the beauties of the face were vail'd!
But I am savager than any beast,
And shall be so till Decius do arive,
Whom with so much submission I have sent
Under my hand, that if he do not bring
His Benediction backe, he must to me
Be much more crueller, then I to you.

sp.speaker: Ero,
sp.l: Is't but your fathers pardon you desire?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: With his love, & then nothing next that, like yours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Decius is come. Enter Decius.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O welcome friend; If I apprehend not
Too much of joy, there's comfort in thy lookes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: There is indeed: I prethee Decius speake it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: How? prethee Decius? this woman's strangly alter'd.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Why dost not speake (good friend) and tell me how
The reverent blessing of my life, received
My humble lines; wept he for joy?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: No, ther's a letter will informe you more:
Yet I can tell you, what I think will grieve you,
The old man is in want, and angry still,
And povertie is the bellowes to the Coale,
More then distast from you as I imagine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's here? how's this? It cannot be: now sure
My griefes delude my senses.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: In his lookes,
I read a world of changes: Decius marke
With what a sad amazement he surveies
The newes: canst thou ghesse what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: None good I feare.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I feare so too: and then—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is her hand.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Too well: if I were ought
But Rock, this Letter would conclude my miseries,
Peruse it (Lady) and resolve me then,
In what a case I stand.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Sir, the worst is,
Your fathers lownesse, and distaste.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Decius,
My sister writes, Fernando has made suite
For love to her: and to expresse sincerely
His constant truth, hath like a noble Gentleman,
Discovered plots of treachery; contriv'd
By false Gonzalo, not intending more
The utter ruine of our house, then generally
Candies confusion.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'Tis a generous part
Of young Fernando.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis, and I could wish
All thrift to his affections Decius.
You find the summe on't Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And can you now yet think a heart opprest
With such a throng of cares, can entertaine
An amorous thought? love frees all toyles but one,
Calamitie and it can ill agree.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wil't please ye speake my doome?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alas great Lady,
Why will you flatter thus a desperate man,
That is quite cast away? O had you not
Procured the Senates warrant to enforce
My stay, I had not heard of these sad newes.
What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Love me, or kill me,
One word shall sentence either: for as truth
Is just, if you refuse me, I am resolute
Not to out-live my thraldome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Gentle Lady.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Say, must I live, or dye?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: My Lord, how can you
Be so inexorable: here's occasion
Of succouring your father in his wants,
Securely profer'd: pray sir, entertaine it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What is my sentence?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What you please to have it?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: As thou art Gentle, speake those words againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, you have prevail'd; yet give me leave
Without offence, ere I resigne the interest
Your heart hath in my heart, to prove your secresie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous, 'tis the greatest Argument
Of thy affections to me.

sp.speaker: Ants
sp.l: Madam, thus then,
My father stands for certaine summes engag'd
To treacherous Gonzalo; and has more 'gag'd
The greatest part of his estate to him:
If you receive this morgage, and procure
Acquitance from Gonzalo to my father,
I am what you would have me be.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You'l love me then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Provided (Madam) that my father know not
I am an Agent for him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: If I faile
In this, I am unworthy to be lov'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then (with your favour) thus I seale my truth,
To day, and Decius witnesse how unchangingly
I shall still love Erota.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thou hast quickned
A dying heart Antinous.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: This is well:
Much happinesse to both. Enter Hyparcha

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: The Lord Gonzalo
Attends you Madam.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Comes as we could wish,
Withdraw Antinous, here's a Closset, where
You may partake his errand; let him enter. Enter

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam you must be wary. Ex. Gonzalo

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Feare it not,
I will be ready for him; to entertaine him
With smiling welcome: Noble sir, you take
Advantage of the time; it had been fit
Some notice of your presence, might have fashion'd
A more prepared state.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: Do ye mocke me Madam?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Trust me, you wrong your judgement, to repute
My gratitude a fault: I have examin'd
Your portly carriage, and will now confesse
It hath not slightly won me.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: The wind's turn'd;
I thought 'twould come to this: it pleas'd us Madam,
At our last interview, to mention love,
Have you consider'd on't?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With more then common
Content: but sir, if what you spake, you meant,
(As I have cause to doubt) then—

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What, (sweet Lady?)

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Methinks me should lay by this forme of statelinesse.
Loves courtship is familiar, and for instance,
See what a change it hath begot in me,
I could talke humbly now, as Lovers use.

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: And I: and I: we meet in one self-center,
Of blest consent.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I hope my weakenesse sir,
Shall not deserve neglect: but if it prove so,
I am not the first Lady has been ruin'd
By being too credulous: you will smart for't one day.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Angell-like-Lady, let me be held it villaine,
If I love not sincerely.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Would I knew it?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Make proofe by any fit command.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, do ye meane to many me?

sp.speaker: Gonz
sp.l: How? meane? nay more, I meane
To make you Empresse of my earthly fortunes,
Regent of my desires, for did ye covet
To be a reall Queene, I could advance you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now I perceive you slight me, and would make me
More simple then my sexes frailety warrants.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: But say your mind, and you shall be a Queene.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: On those conditions, call me yours.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Enough,
But are we safe?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: In short,
Yet Lady first be plaine: would you not choose
Much rather to prefer your own Sun-rising,
Then any's else though ne're so neere entituled
By bloud, or right of birth?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Tis a question
Needs not a resolution.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Good: what if
I set the Crowne of Candy on your head?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I were a Queene indeed then.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Madam, know
There's but a boy 'twixt you, and it suppose him
Transhap'd into an Angell.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wise Gonzalo,
I cannot but admire thee.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'Tis worth thinking on:
Besides your husband shall be Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Gonzalo, Duke of Venice?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Ye are mine ye say.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Pish: you but dally with me; and would lull me
In a rich golden dreame.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: You are too much distrustfull of my truth.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you must give me leave to apprehend
The meanes, and manner how.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why thus—

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You shall not,
We may be over-heard; Affaires and counsels
Of such high nature, are not to be trusted
Not to the Aire it selfe, you shall in writing,
Draw out the full designe; which if effected,
I am as I professe.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O I applaud
Your ready care, and secresie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Gonzalo,
There is a bar yet, twixt our hopes and us,
And that must be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Old Cassilane.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: He? feare not him: I build upon his ruines
Already.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I would find a smoother course
To shift him off.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wee'l talke in private,
I have a ready plot.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I shall adore you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, although I hate unnoble practices,
And therefore have perform'd no more then what
I ought, for honours safety: yet Annophil,
Thy love hath been the spur, to urge me forward
For speedier diligence.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Sir your owne fame
And memory will best reward themselves.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: All gaine is losse (sweet beauty) if I misse
My comforts here: The brother and the sister
Have double conquer'd me, but thou maist triumph.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Good sir, I have a father.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, a brave one;
Could'st thou obscure thy Beauty, yet the happinesse
Of being but his daughter, were a dowre
Fit for a Prince: what say ye?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: You have deserv'd
As much as I should grant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this faire hand
I take possession.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: What in words I dare not,
Imagine in my silence.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou art all vertue.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I'le tell thee how: Baldwin the Emperour,
Pretending title, more through tyranny,
Then right of conquest, or descent, usurp'd
The stile of Lord o're all the Grecian Islands,
And under colour of an amity
With Creet, preferd the Marquesse Mountferato
To be our Governor; the Cretians vex'd
By the ambitious Turkes, in hope of aide
From the Emperour, received for Generall,
This Mountferato; he (the wars appeased)
Plots with the state of Venice, and takes money
Of them for Candy: they paid well, he steales
Away in secret; since which time, that right
The state of Venice claimes o're Candy, is
By purchase, not inheritance, or Conquest:
And hence growes all our quarrell.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: So a usurer
Or Lumbard-Jew, might with some bags of trash,
Buy halfe the Westerne world.

sp.speaker: Cas
sp.l: Money Arcanes
Is now a God on earth: it cracks virginities,
And turnes a Christian, Turke;
Bribes justice, cut-throats honour, does what not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not captives Candy.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Nor makes thee dishonest,
Nor me a Coward— Now sir, here is homely,
But friendly entertainment.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I find it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: And like it, do ye not?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My repaire speakes for me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Fernando we were speaking off— how this?
